newsitem.title: FIJI: FEATURE - Traders skirt the issues at tiny Fiji bourse.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Traders skirt the issues at tiny Fiji bourse.

text.p: It's 10 minutes before the opening of trading at the Suva Stock Exchange and you could cut the tension in the humid atmosphere with a swaying palm leaf.

Part-time dealers in traditional sulu skirts line up opposite a trading board, while a "chalkie" in an orange and blue sari gets ready to register the trades in shares for the exchange's four listed companies on a whiteboard.
Exchange manager Mesake Nawari, a jolly Fijian in crisp white shirt and tie and grey sulu, smiles in anticipation -- his exchange only trades once a week on Monday morning and for 30 minutes.
There are no stock brokers in Fiji, so in an attempt to stimulate trading, an open call system has just been introduced.
Australian Tony Cooper, local media manager for Australia's Westpac Banking Corp, has volunteered to be the caller.
"I just help them out on Monday mornings for a bit of fun," says Cooper. "I call all the stocks and we also have government bonds, quasi bonds and government securities."
Cooper rings a small, golden bell and the exchange is, well, if not quite abuzz, open for business.
Cooper invites interest in the first listed company, Burns Philip Toyota (South Seas) Ltd, but buyer and seller can't agree on a price and there is no trade.

The next company, Flour Mills of Fiji Ltd, sees a nerve wracking trade between buyer and seller, who exchange 13 prices, mostly quoting in one cent lots until they finally agree and 2,000 shares trade at F$2.03 (US$1.58).
Unfortunately the remaining two companies, Fiji Sugar Corporation and South Pacific Distilleries Ltd, fail to trade.

Traders here know the real action is on the secondary bond market. This morning Housing Authority (Short Term) Bonds with a face value of F$100,000 and coupon of 7.82 percent, maturing December 31, 1998, are sold at F$101.85.
"Bonds are the growth area," says a confident Lionel Yee, stock exchange chairman and head of the Fiji National Provident Fund, currently the main source of domestic investment in Fiji.

"The bonds are quite a lucrative market in terms of fixed interest. But people are not used to buying and selling bonds," Yee told Reuters, adding he hoped that once word spread, bonds would challenge local banks for depositors' savings.
The Fiji government last month started trading debt from its bankrupt National Bank of Fiji on the exchange and plans to convert some F$160-200 million in debt, says Yee.
He declines to disclose when the next bond will be released.
In a town where everybody knows everybody, such sensitive information could move the market -- anyway its against the exchange rules adopted from the Australian Stock Exchange.
Yee says two trades is a healthy morning at the exchange, although he recalls proudly a record F$5-6 million turnover one morning. "It's not New York or Sydney," he says.

Increased bond trading and the possible partial float next year of Fiji Post & Telecom, which posted a F$18.8 million profit in calendar 1995, will hopefully provide enough liquidity for a screen-based trading system, says Yee.
By the end of 1996 he hopes to have an overseas trading facility for Fijians to trade out of Australia and New Zealand.
The government has exempted residents from a five percent tax on dividends for listed companies and abolished stamp duties on trades in an attempt to attract investors.
But the exchange needs at least 30 companies for long-term viability, says Nawari.
The Suva Stock Exchange was formed in 1979, but prior to July this year, it operated as a trading post where trading of securities by both buyer and seller was handled by the exchange.

"This was largely due to the absence of a trading floor and broker community," says Nawari in his modern, but small, exchange on Victoria Parade along Suva Harbour. An electronic tickerboard at the entrance diplays the latest trades.
Exchange chairman Lionel Yee says the choice was either to close the exchange or open a trading floor and hope it encouraged activity.
In 1995, the volume of shares and bonds traded was 66,023 and F$155.5 million respectively. Since July, 120,533 shares have changed hands and F$21.8 million worth of bonds.
Nawari said most trades are by institutional dealers.
"There are no stockbrokers, but we hope that the 24 part-time dealers with the stock exchange will encourage a brokerage community," he says.
But despite its small size, trading on the Suva Stock Exchange is a tough game for dealers.

"You missed a trade," barks Yee to a young female dealer after the close of the Monday morning session. "You have to attract the buyer. You only get a split second to get on and you have to put the highest price on the board."
